intro: Verbesina tamaulipana, commonly known as Tamaulipan beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant has stiff, hairy stems and leaves that are typically heart-shaped with serrated edges. Its showy yellow flowers bloom in the summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including roadsides and open woodlands.
